comment._content: Founded by African-American educator Booker T. Washington in Tuskegee, Alabama in 1881 as the Tuskegee Normal School for Colored Teachers, later known as the Tuskegee Institute and now as Tuskegee University, Tuskegee is a private, historically Black university. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tuskegee_University

comment.author: 74978265@N00
comment._content: I find no direct evidence that this is either the Tuskeegee School or Institute, although that is likely.  The caption says "Hospital-Tuskeegee" and no more.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: It's true that the caption doesn't identify the hospital as being connected with the Institute. However, all the circumstantial evidence (its placement in a series of pictures of college activities and people closely connected with the Institute at the time of Booker T. Washington's death, the racial makeup of the nurses and patients, etc.) marks it as almost unmistakably taken in the Institute's hospital. This was John A. Andrew Memorial Hospital, which claimed to be the first full-service hospital for the treatment of Black patients. Perhaps more importantly, due to racial discrimination, it was one of the few places in the Jim Crow South where Black doctors and medical professionals could work. It was opened in February, 1913. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2641895/?page=3 www.encyclopediaofalabama.org/face/Article.jsp?id=h-2410 Also, Tuskegee was and is a very small place (even today, with a university, there are only 11,000 people. The likelihood that it had a second hospital of this kind is very small.
